Then about  a week ago I'm driving on the highway  and I got to thinking about Mary and  suddenly I couldn't breathe...I  couldn't keep up with the flow of  traffic anymore I felt like I was  going to die. I pulled into a rest  area, parked the car, and just started  shaking. The Psychiatrist scratches his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know...rest areas are homosexual  hang-outs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Highway rest areas--they're the  bathhouses of the nineties for some  gay men. Ted thinks about this, then glances back at the shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking wristwatch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops, time's up. We'll have to delve  into that next week. Off Ted's look, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and his friend DOM are blasting a couple buckets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay? He said you were gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He implied it.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you're a writer, and a lot of  writers are gay. Look at Truman  Capote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he was successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this: When you smoke  a cigar, do you ever pretend it has  balls? Ted appears to think about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, that wouldn't make me gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to fix you up with my new  assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he like? Dom LAUGHS, then watches as Ted hits a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving it out. Finish your  swing. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to like this one--she's  half Asian, half American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-looking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just told you, she's half Asian.  half American. They're all good  looking. You could mate Don Rickles  and Yoko Ono and they're going to  have a gorgeous kid. It's a foolproof  combo. Ted thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point? Let's face it,  Dom, I'm in a slump. (SIGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lately I've been feeling  like...well...like a loser.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser? You? Ted shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break. Remember five years  ago, when your kidneys failed? If  you were a loser would they have  been able to find a donor with an  exact tissue match? What are the  odds of that, one in a million?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so I'm lucky because my brother  got killed in an explosion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that. I'm saying your  lucky those kids found his kidneys. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, your brother Jimmy never  gave a shit about you. Ted gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're a real glass-is- half-empty guy. You got a fucking  guardian angel, man. Ted manages a small smile. Just then, Ted's cell phone RI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta take this, it might be my  boss. (flips phone open)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cocksucking motherfucking  piece of puke! Whoever it is HANGS UP. Without reacting, Ted closes the  phone and puts it back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dom and Ted are drinking beer while sitting on Dom's fron steps. We see signs of kids everywhere: a tricycle, six-foot  basketball hoop, dolls, etc. DOM'S WIFE comes out and hands them each a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you guys might like these  with your beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, baby. She goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's what I want. I don't  need these bimbettes you got me  chasing. I want what you have. A  family....Someone to...you  know...love. These guys don't usually talk about this crap, and Ted ge a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be great with a wife like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each day is better than the next. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been, you know...in  love with someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well once. Mary. Dom SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary again.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I admit it was brief, but it  was definitely love. Crushes don't  last twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever happened to Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, her family moved to Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean since then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why don't you look her up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I guarantee she's married  and has a couple kids. Girls like  Mary don't stay single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you're wrong? You just said  she's the only girl you ever loved,  what have you got to lose by calling  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did try calling her. (sheepish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few years ago. She wasn't listed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that was it? One bump in the road  and you gave up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also called Unsolved Mysteries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding? What did they say?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told me they don't help out  stalkers. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, maybe they're right, it's been  a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it--you hire a private eye,  fly him out there, he follows her  around a couple days, she'll never  know a thing. Ted considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No fucking way. That's too creepy. Dom thinks a moment, then SNAPS his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second. There's a guy named  Healy in my office who might be able  to help you out. He's a claims  investigator and he goes to Miami  every couple weeks. As Ted thinks about this, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Dom are walking down a hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about this, Dom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, this guy owes me a big one. A  couple years ago he got in a jam up  in the Boston office; some bullshit  about padding his resume--like we  haven't all done that.  Anyway, they  were going to let him go but his  mother wrote a tear-jerker letter  that ended up on my desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess he still lives with  her.  Seemed like a sweet lady--got  diabetes or something--so I went out  on a limb and got him transferred  down to Providence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think he could find out her  number for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll do better than that. I'll send  him down to Miami on business, you  throw him a couple bucks on the side,  and he'll track her down. Ted thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me warn you--This guy runs  a little hot, but he gets the job  done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is seated inside a small cubicle across the desk from PATRICK HEALY, a shaggy-looking guy in a mis-matched thre piece suit. Healy looks more like a used-car salesman than an insuran investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Dom tells me you're looking for  some lady-friend you knew in high  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea where I might start looking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moved to Miami Beach twelve years  ago.  I checked directory assistance  down there and she's not listed. She  might've moved ten times since then.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you want is a phone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know you're busy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play games with me, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe you could poke  around for a half day and see if she  has five kids and a Labrador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't buy what? Suddenly Healy is in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, I'm the kind of guy who shoots  from the hip. Now I want you to level  with me: Did you knock this skirt  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's blackmailing you, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more indignant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want her dead, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really expect me to believe  this is a straight stalker case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a stalker! She's a friend of  mine.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure she is. That's why she got an  unlisted number and you haven't heard  squat from her in a dozen years. Oh  you're good, Ted.  You're a real  piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, let's forget it. Let's forget  the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get one hundred a day plus expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS at Healy's  nerve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get fifty a day, period. It's a  business trip, they'll pay for your  expenses. Healy thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ted, I'll do it. But if this  chick turns up with a toe tag, I'm  rolling over on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy waits alone on a corner carrying one bag and a RACK BEERS. Suddenly a '89 Chrysler Lebaron convertible with a GREAT DANE in the back SCREECHES to a halt in front of hi The driver, SULLY, is a muscular, well-groomed man in his thirties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy you dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking out car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Sully! Look at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Boston accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hot shit. Ya look fuckin' pisser.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog is catching wind in the backseat and Sully hands  Healy a packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the info you asked for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should thank me--that girl was  not easy to find. What'd she scam  you out of-some insurance dough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, some guy threw me a few bucks  to track down his high school  girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalker, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is modest and clean but it has a direct view o South Beach. Healy puts his bags down and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing okay. (checks watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get ready for work. Sully ducks into the bedroom and Healy looks around the  apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? With this pad, the killer  wheels?  Looks like you really cleaned  up your act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I tell you?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a healthier lifestyle down here,  and it's easier to succeed when your  head's clear. Those guys I worked  with back in Boston, they were a bad  influence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' animals. Hey, what do you  say we go grab a couple drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, buddy. I don't drink  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you don't drink any less,  right? Suddenly a huge Boa Constrictor slithers up on Healy's la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...?! Sully comes back in the room wearing a police uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, that's Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Bill to get the fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, he just ate. Healy just stares at his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen months I been sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You were  never an alky, you were a cokehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well when you quit blow, you  gotta quit the booze, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? Well good for you,  Sull, I'm proud of you.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 Healy pops open one of his beers and hands it to Sully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, just have one of these then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy, what I just tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a light beer. You can't have  a light beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I can't. Healy stares at him, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully, it's one fuckin' beer for  Christ sakes. (holds up beer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, the big bad beer's gonna get  ya. Sully stares at the beer, weakening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried about you, man. You better  learn to have a pop once in a while  or you're gonna fall off the wagon.  You're being a fanatic and that ain't  healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet your ass you are. Now I don't  want to hear anymore of your happy  horseshit. You gotta learn how to  bend a little or believe me...you're  gonna break. Finally, Sully takes the beer. He stares at it a moment a then sips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you know what? This shit  doesn't even taste good to me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, fuck ya then, you big pussy.  What are you, spotting?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 Healy takes the beer from Sully and as he chugs it, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy is on a stakeout. He's dozing. He's been here for h food wrappers litter Sully's car. He's wearing Walkman-ty HEADPHONES which are connected to a RADIO SURVEILLANCE  MICROPHONE attached to a pair of BINOCULARS. Suddenly MUSIC explodes through his headphones--Healy's j awake. Who threw the grenade? Recovering, Healy aims the  binoculars toward...

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S APARTMENT ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: Healy has a clear, unobstructed view into Mary's apartmen The music is coming from Mary's clock radio. MARY sits up bed and shakes herself awake, like someone's just poured  cold water over her. She cranks the music even LOUDER. Ma hops out of bed, wearing only her panties, and though she a little older now, she still looks well cast. CLOSE UP - ON HEALY - he's become extremely interested in his work. As much as Healy's enjoying the show, he's got job to do--he speaks into a MICRO-CASSETTE RECORDER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into recorder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ted, I found your Mary. Her  current address, two-niner-eight  Euclid Avenue, Miami Beach. Husband,  negative. Children and Labrador,  negative. Extremely nice ass,  affirmative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks into the living room where we see an old woman MAGDA, sitting on the couch LISTENING to a stack of RADIO SCANNERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been up all night again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet your ass I have. It's an important  job, Neighborhood Watch is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighborhood Watch?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you call listening in  on stranger's phone conversations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These ain't strangers, they're  neighbors.  This only picks up signals  in a half-mile radius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning these are the people you  live amongst, you got a right to  know if they're creeps. For instance,  did you know there's a guy down the  hall cheating on his wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning shock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You picked that up on the scanner.  We gotta move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I confirmed it on the scanner. I  knew something was up because Puffy  used to bark like hell whenever he  saw him and you know Puffy only barks  at bad people. Magda pats her little dog PUFFY on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magda, Puffy barks at everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because there's a lot of bad  people out there. Hey, Puffy tried  to warn you about that Steve guy you  was seeing--he was a fucking asswipe-- but you had to find out for yourself,  didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you win. Now try to get some  sleep, huh. Mary gives Magda a kiss and heads to her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC MONTAGE - as Healy follows Mary around town.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary exits her apartment and bounces out into the world.  There is a HOMELESS MAN sitting on the sidewalk. Mary fli him an apple, then jumps in her Honda Civic and drives of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is at the range HITTING a couple buckets of balls. ON HEALY - watching from the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we got an athlete on our  hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary waits in the drive-thru lane reading the SPORTS PAGE Finally the window opens and she is handed a HUGE BAG OF  FOOD. PAN TO Healy watching from his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, from her figure and her  appetite, I'm guessing she's either  got a bowel disorder or we've got a  hurler on our hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's brother Warren is wearing a walkman as he plays ca out front with a SPECIAL ED TEACHER while several other  MENTALLY-DISABLED PATIENTS entertain themselves. Mary pulls up, gets out, and starts handing out Egg McMuf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in line. One at a time. A fat patient, GARY, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have two, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can have two halves, just  like everyone else.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Gary takes his and walks off. A couple more patients and  then bucktoothed FREDDIE steps up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, pretty boy? And what about  Dolores? Mary points to another PATIENT staring bashfully at Fredd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you marry us both, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that'd be a good deal for you,  wouldn't it? Freddie moves off and fat Gary is back, trying to be  inconspicuous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, this is weird. There was somebody  who looked just like you here a minute  ago. Mary smiles and hands Gary another McMuffin. CLOSE ON Healy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ixnay on the big appetite. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just got a big heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighborhood restaurant and bar. After-work crowd. Mary a her friends, BRENDA, LISA, and JOANIE are sitting at a ta under an umbrella. Lisa reads from the PERSONALS COLUMN i South Beach Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this one--'Seeking sensitive  Wasp doctor to share candlelit  dinners, long walks in Coconut Grove,  marriage.'
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this girl want, a corpse?   You gotta be more specific: 'Seeking  deaf mute with three pound cock and  trust fund.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it should be 'a hockey player  with great pecs.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh, not pecs. Sounds like one of  those guys with a fish-net shirt and  a banana hammock. PAN TO the bar where we see Healy eavesdropping on their  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you wouldn't like someone  with a washboard stomach like Brad  Pitt? BACK ON Mary and friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying I don't mind a guy  with a bit of a beer belly. It means  he's a guy.  You can have those pretty  boys who hang out in a gym all day  staring at their reflections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly into mic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl after your own heart, Ted. BACK ON Mary and friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can live with those reflections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of these calorie-countin'  pansies.  Give me a guy who likes  kielbasa and beer and playing thirty- six holes and still has enough energy  to take me and Warren out to a  ballgame.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, I don't know where you're ever  going to find a guy like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But here's the rub. The guy I'm  talking about has got to be self- employed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, like an architect or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Architect, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean creative, but not poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not the money. Creative,  yeah, that's good, but it's the  freedom I'm talking about. See, this  guy has to have a job he could do  anywhere. That way we could just up  and leave at the drop of a hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where would you and your beer- bellied architect be leaving to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. The Super Bowl, New  Orleans Jazz Festival...maybe a couple  months in Nepal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you'd probably dump the  poor guy halfway to Katmandu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means you're too hard on guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come off it, Mare. What about  what's-his-name...Steverino? You  could've at least passed the baton  on that one. The girls LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Steve. Steve was all right for  awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right for awhile? The guy's good- looking, rich, witty. He was a god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one point you were talking about  marrying him. Come on, why'd you  dump him? Mary thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, it was complicated.  He's in San Francisco, I'm in Miami. (dodging question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, Magda's psychic dog hated  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that old crab still with you?  Mary, you said you were putting her  up for a month--it's been a year and  a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, she's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, cut the crap, what really  happened with Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I mean, you know my brother. (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Steve seemed to put up with  Warren.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want someone who'll put up  with him. I want someone who will  enjoy him, the way I do. Do you know  what he told my friend Tucker?  He  said he would've popped the question  a lot earlier if Warren wasn't in my  life. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he is in my life and I'm goddamn  lucky to have him. The hell with  Steve. Everyone is touched by this. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the last time I blow  him behind your back. As the girls LAUGH, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy sits out front in his car again waiting for Mary to get home. He picks up the phone, dials a number, and some answers but doesn't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...? Sully...? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully, that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully, it's Healy. What's going on  over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sully is sitting on the kitchen floor in his police unifo a ring of white around his nostrils. The room is littered with beer cans, he has another one in his hand, there's a pile of cocaine and a rolled-up bill on the breakfast tab The dog and the snake are in the doorway looking at him w concern.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, sloshed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' Patrick Healy, you think  your shit don't stink. Well I got  news for you--you're goddamn right  it don't! How the hell are ya?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy looks at the phone, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I'm fine. Just wanted to let you  know I'll have your car back in a  couple hours, I'm still staking out  this girl's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found my car?! Just then Healy notices Mary pull up and park. He slides  down in his seat. ON MARY - she gets out carrying a bag and approaches the  Homeless Man, who is still sitting on the sidewalk. She h him the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch out for yourself, Herb. As Mary bounds up the steps of her building, we HOLD ON t Homeless Man as he happily takes a sandwich and soda out the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary rushes into the apartment, Magda is glued to her  radio scanner, listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary, you gotta hear this-- some cop's staking out this broad's  apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time, Magda, my show's starting. BACK ON HEALY...
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 ... he can hear the conversation through the SURVEILLANCE EQUIPMENT pointed at Mary's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a good one, Mare. Sounds  like his partner's all lubed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I miss ya, ya fuck- Healy hangs up abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Christ, I lost 'em. Mary runs into her bedroom, shuts the door and flips on t tube just as ESPN Sportscenter's OPENING THEME SONG is  playing. Relieved, Mary lays back on her bed and starts watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is now watching Andy Griffith while SMOKING A JOINT GIGGLING away in bed. ON HEALY - he's sitting in his car, GIGGLING, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Barney...he never learns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the show's end credits start to WHISTLE AWAY, Mary sta and starts to UNDRESS for bed. BACK ON HEALY - he sits up, very interested now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go, Teddo. Here comes the  money shot.

Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 Healy quickly reaches in the back seat and pulls out a bi MORE POWERFUL PAIR OF BINOCULARS. HEALY'S BINOCULAR POV - we're CLOSE ON the wrinkliest,  saggiest, droopiest set of milkbags on the planet. ON HEALY - he cringes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooof. First chink in the armor,  Teddy Boy.... HEALY'S BINOCULAR POV - He moves his view up from the tit to reveal...MAGDA UNDRESSING for bed. ON HEALY - He flinches, sickened by his mistake, then  repositions the binoculars dead left to the next window. HEALY'S BINOCULAR POV - moving over to the next window we see... Mary as she just finishes putting on some sexy t-shirt. ON HEALY - as he starts to drool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweet Jesus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is sitting alone having a beer when a smiling Healy  approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some very, very good news  for you, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? (perking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very, very? Healy sits down and motions for a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think your life's about to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you found Mary?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there in Liberty City. And you  were right, she's really something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she hasn't changed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I couldn't. say. Let me ask you  something: Was she a little big-boned  in high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well she must've packed on a few  pounds over the years. This doesn't dampen Ted's enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's a little chubby, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say about a deuce, deuce and a  half.  Not bad. Ted's smile starts to fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know, you shit out a bunch  of kids, you're going to put on a  few pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she's married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. Never been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four kids, three different guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three different guys?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm guessing. There's a black  kid, two whites, and a midget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyperactive little fuckers, too.  Tough to keep up with in a wheelchair,  I bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in a wheelchair?! Ted looks completely drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look so shocked, it's been a  long time. I bet you've changed a  lot over the last twelve years,  haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that...Mary. I wouldn't  have thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, the good news is I have all  the information you need. Got it  from her bookie--nice guy. You should  definitely call her, Ted. I mean  she's a real sparkplug, that one.  She seems determined to get those  rugrats off welfare and with your  help I'll bet she does it. Ted stands and starts moping away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Healy. Good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted? Don't you want the name of the  housing project?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure, big guy?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet she'd love to hear from you  before her mastectomy! As Ted leaves, Healy puts his feet up on the table and si back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN across the room of unopened boxes to Ted laying aw in bed. We hear HEAD-BANGER MUSIC coming from the apartme next door. Finally Ted gets up and walks over to his dres As he flips on a small light we see loose change, a balle up Kleenex, a few golf tees, and Ted's wallet. Ted picks the wallet and opens it. TED'S POV - Inside is an an old high school photo of a sm Mary. As Ted looks at it, he can't help but smile, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HEALY'S CUBICLE - Healy's taking his last boxload of c out of his cubicle when he spots Ted. He tries to duck ba in but Ted sees him. Healy forces a smile as Ted approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, I resigned. Ted picks up a plane ticket off the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miami?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this insurance business is too  slow for me. I'm going to go down  and try my hand at jai alai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jai alai?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't know why but I always  felt at home in the fronton. Healy starts walking out of the office and Ted follows. H is having a hard time looking him in the eye. So he doesn
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, uh, I've been thinking about  everything you told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I think you're right, I should  look her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rollerpig? Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said she was a sparkplug...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said buttplug. She's heinous. Ted SIGHS and follows Healy out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk across the lot toward Healy's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the same, I still want to call  her. I know it sounds crazy--Mary  sure has a lot of troubles in her  life--but, I don't know, maybe I can  help her out. (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor thing's had it tough--she's  in a wheelchair for Godsakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a goddamn bunion. It'll heal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not it anyway. I know this  doesn't make any sense to you, but I  just can't turn it off that fast. I  still feel something for her. Healy comes to his car and puts his stuff in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, tell you what: I'll get her  number for you just as soon as she  gets back from Japan.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Japan? What's she doing in Japan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've heard of mail-order brides?  Well they go that way, too. Ted is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's a mail-order bride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetched a pretty penny, too. Don't  forget, it's the Sumo culture, they  pay by the pound there. Sort of like  tuna. Off Ted's look, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Dom are having a beer and a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, I'm making an oath. I'll  never procrastinate about anything  again. Life is too fucking short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look on the bright side--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Dom? What's the bright  side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...at least now you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was better when I didn't.  It was kind of inspiring to know  there was someone so pure in the  world. As Ted dwells on this, Dom bursts out LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, it's just that you're  taking this all wrong, pal. Don't  you see? You're liberated. I feel  liberated. I mean here you've been  in therapy thinking you blew it with  the greatest girl ever, and it turns  out that getting your dick stuck in  your zipper was the best thing that  ever happened to you! Ted flinches at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second, I never told you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Ted, I was only four towns  away. Ted thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're right. I should look on  the bright side. I mean, I've still  got my health... (checks watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm out of here. I've got to get up  at six a.m. to move my boss's brother  into his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? On your day off? Do you even  know the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ted, you've got to finish  that damn novel so you can quit that  stupid magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy pays for a bucket of balls, then takes his clubs an strolls jauntily to...
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: GOLF TEE NEXT TO MARY'S
dialogues.text: Healy places a ball on the tee and takes a swing. He tops the ball and it dribbles about ten yards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit a house! Bite bite! (to Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't swung the wrenches in a while. Mary nods. Healy takes another swing and duck-hooks one a fifty yards. Mary addresses her ball, takes a smooth  backswing, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, can you give me some tips here? She cracks her shot long and straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't talk in someone's  backswing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Mary tees up another ball and Healy puts down his club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get a soda, you want one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. Healy pulls out a huge wad of change from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh cripes. Do you have change for a  dollar?  All I have is these stupid  Nepalese coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nepal? Have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in months. I don't even know why  I bought the damn place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You own a home there?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...it's just a condo really.  Right outside Katmandu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That's a place I've always wanted  to go. Is it true the mountains are  so tall you can't see the tops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not 'til you get about three hundred  yards from the summit. That's been  my experience anyway. She looks impressed. Healy looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I should just get going.  I'll work on my game next week. He flips her a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Spend it on your trip to  Katmandu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Healy starts to walk off. Mary doesn't know what to do. W she ever see this guy again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CALLS after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice meeting you! Healy doesn't answer or turn around. He just raises his h and gives her a little wave. Mary shrugs her shoulders. Oh well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy is sitting in Sully's Chrysler LeBaron, right next Mary's Honda Civic. He watches the rear-view mirror, and the moment he sees M coming out from the driving range, he swings his legs out the door and starts changing out of his golf shoes. As Ma tosses her golf bag into the trunk, she notices Healy tyi his shoes. A second chance.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was nice meeting you, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat Healy. There's an uncomfortable pause...Why doesn't this guy ask the usual questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already know it, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right there on your golf bag. Healy opens the back door to put away his golf shoes.  Suddenly, rolls and rolls of paper come tumbling out. Mar bends over to help Healy pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing with all these  blueprints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some buildings I'm working on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you...an architect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just until I get my PGA Tour  card. Mary stares at him, mouth agape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kidding. Yeah, I guess you could  call me an architect--it's just a  job really, a way to keep me moving.  My real passion is my hobby.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work with retards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... (flaps lips with  fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the guys who ride the short bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (put off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a little politically  incorrect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell with that. No one's gonna  tell me who I can and can't work  with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --There's this one kid, we call him  Mongo on account of he's a mongoloid.  He got out of his cage once and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --He's in a cage?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's more of an enclosure really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep him confined? That's  bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said, so I went out  and got him a leash you know, one of  those clothesline runners for the  backyard. He's got plenty of room  out there to dig. The kid's really  blossomed. Now I can take him to  ball games, movies--you know, happy  stuff.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's fun for them, but it's  heaven for me. (getting emotional)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those goofy bastards are just about  the best thing I have in this crazy  old world. (checks watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, hey, I gotta run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (won back over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, uh, I was thinking maybe we  should go have dinner sometime. Healy smiles at this and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A profusely sweating Ted has a DRESSER ON HIS BACK and EE his way toward the front door as his BOSS'S DISABLED BROT catches up to him IN A WHEELCHAIR. (The man is a quadripl who needs to use a MOUTHPIECE to operate his chair.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, shit-for-brains, be careful not  to scratch that thing, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me. You already put a  fucking nick in my piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (biting tongue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try to be more careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'matter with you? You look like  you're fading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing's kind of heavy.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy? Heavy?! What I wouldn't give  to know what heavy feels like, you  insensitive prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just meant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah. I'm going to the corner  to get a cup of coffee. The Boss's Disabled Brother bites into the mouthpiece and ZIPS AWAY up the sidewalk. Ted takes a step. Rests. A ste Rests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you! Ted glances back toward the street to see a T.V. NEWS REP from the CHANNEL 7 I-TEAM rushing toward him with a NEWS  CREW on her heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that you're parked in a  handicapped spot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is splayed out on a table in obvious pain while DR.  LALONDE, an old high school pal, palpates his spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smirking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...I see you made the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry and embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my truck--I was helping  out a guy in a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Where was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out getting coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's more or less what the  others said, too. Out getting  coffee...supposed to meet him  here...picking up my grandma... Ted turns and GLARES at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying...They sure made you  look dumb. Ted SIGHS. A couple big CRACKS of the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, do you remember Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From high school Mary? Yeah, I saw  her about six months ago at a  convention in Las Vegas. Ted sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A convention? How'd you see her at a  convention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an orthopedic surgeon, she's an  orthopedic surgeon. The Doc SIGHS, still able to recall the feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a babe... Ted sits up on his elbows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buckled-over Ted limps into Dom's office with a crazed  look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's a babe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Mary--she's not in Japan, she's  single, and she's got no rugrats.  She does have a little gambling  problem, she plays the football cards  a bit too much, but she's a babe, a  surgeon babe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? But why did Healy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well think about it. Ted folds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No You mean...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lazy fuck just didn't bother to  look her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sneaky prick was probably  practicing his jai alai. Dom shakes his head. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then you've got to call her,  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck calling her. I'm going down  there.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Mary gets ready for her date, Magda sits in front o the radio scanner in her bathrobe with her little dog Puf on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who's the lucky guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Patrick, I met him at the  driving range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good lookin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no Steve Young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy, listening through his headphones, reacts to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He's kind of a mook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a mook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a mookalone, a schlep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why you going out with him if  he's a schlep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Magda (SIGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like that movie Harold and Maude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't watch the new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's almost thirty years old.  It's about a young kid and an old  lady who fall in love.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly why I don't watch 'em  anymore--it's bullshit! Why the hell  would an old lady go for a young  kid? Mary smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, love isn't about money  or social standing or age, it's about  connecting with someone, having things  in common kindred spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck kindred spirits. My little Puffy  here's gonna tell you all you need  to know about this guy in about two  seconds flat. If he starts yapping, he's a loser; if Puffy's relaxed... you got yourself a keeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy tiptoes up to Mary's apartment door. He peeks throu the mail slot. HEALY'S POV - Puffy is staring at him and GROWLING. Healy reaches in his pocket, pulls out a VALIUM and a DOG TREAT. Healy shoves the pill into the treat's soft center, exami it, then thinks what the hell and SHOVES IN ANOTHER ONE. Puffy GROWLS LOUDER. Healy pops the treat through the mai slot and listens as the dog DEVOURS IT. Healy looks at hi watch, then sneaks back outside to wait a few minutes for the drugs to kick in.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy is sitting on Mary's couch with Puffy spread-eagled upside-down on his lap, KNOCKED OUT COLD. Mary and Magda  look on in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (baby talk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Pufferball likes his little tum- tum rubbed, doesn't he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, I've never seen him like this.  He doesn't usually like guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean he doesn't like bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'That right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can tell you're an animal nut.  You are, aren't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth is I usually get along better  with animals than with people. In  Nepal the villagers call me 'Kin-tan- tee', which means 'man who is loved  by many animals... (babbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who love him a lot, too...and so  on.' Magda stares dreamily at Healy, smitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a glass of tea or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a brew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (noticing Magda's  trance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Magda, why don't you get some  more cheese and crackers...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, of course, dear.

Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 The two women go into the kitchen and Healy is left to pe the MOTIONLESS DOG. Suddenly Healy notices that the dog i LITTLE TOO MOTIONLESS. Healy checks Puffy's pulse. He loo at his watch to time the rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CALLING out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Pat, out of beer. You like  vodka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CALLING out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. He starts SHAKING THE DOG, but Puffy doesn't move. Healy  goes into action. He starts pressing on his heart, PERFOR DOGGIE CPR. One-and-two-and-three, he continues trying to revive him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CALLING out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a little clam-dip,  honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CALLING out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. (panicking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love a little bundt cake if you have  some!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magda and Mary are on their way out the door when they st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundt cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have a sweet tooth. See if you  can find some cookies. As Magda starts to go through the cupboards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panicked Healy is giving the little mutt MOUTH-TO-MOUTH now. Then back to the heart, the mouth, the heart, the mouth..
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, desperately,  to Puffy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man, stay away from the  light! Healy resumes blowing into the dog's snout, pumping his c with no results. Desperate, he picks up the cheese knife quickly SLICES THE WIRES ON TWO TABLE LAMPS. Healy grabs the two wires and TOUCHES THEM TOGETHER LIKE DEFIBRILLATOR on the little pooch's chest. ZZZZZTTTTTT - the dog BOUNCES a couple feet off the couch SPARKS FLY. Healy takes his pulse again. Nothing. He ZAPS him once mo with the LIVE WIRES. ZZZZZTTTTT - Still nothing. Healy gets to his feet and pe into the kitchen. When he turns his back, we see PUFFY IG

dialogues.speaker: FLAMES.
dialogues.text: When Healy turns back, he's horrified at what he sees. He grabs a vase of flowers and POURS THE WATER ON THE BURNIN DOG. With this, Puffy flinches and comes to, GASPING FOR AIR!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I had was some Funny Bones--how  does that sound, honey? Healy picks up the stunned pooch and swaddles it in a bla as Magda ENTERS the room followed by Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (petting dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go. (sniffs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that smell? Mary hands Healy his vodka and as he downs it, we
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy looks slightly disoriented as Mary leads the way in the courtyard area by the main building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The museum? I thought we were going  out to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will, but first I have a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A surprise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The architecture exhibit! My friend  Tucker is going to be here. He's an  architect, too. You guys will have  tons to talk about. CLOSE ON HEALY'S FACE as he starts to panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Healy walk through the exhibit area. Mary scans room for her friend. Healy's face is ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's around here someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chipper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What say we get outta here and go  crush a bucket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just got here thirty seconds ago.  Isn't this stuff great? Mary points to an architectural model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this one art deco or art nouveau?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you call that a portico or a  vestibule?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...? Vestibule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you look at architecture, try  not to concern yourself with the  pieces--look at the building in its  totalitarianism. Mary gives him a look. Suddenly, Healy draws a couple of  invisible sixshooters at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone crab time! Come on, let's get  outta here, goofy. He turns to go but Mary notices something O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tucker! Mary leads Healy over to her friend TUCKER, a distinguish looking man in his fifties. Healy looks like a dog that's being dragged to the vet. Mary and Tucker embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still hugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, like you mean it. Mary LAUGHS and hugs Tucker tighter. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tucker, this is my friend Pat Healy. Healy and Tucker shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat's an architect, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, no kidding? Where are your  offices?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping cool)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mainly I work out of Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boston, huh? Did you get your degree  up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes yes, I did get my degree up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you study under Kim Greene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim and I are close friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell her I ran into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean him. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...that's debatable. Healy makes a hand-gesture to imply that Kim's sexuality in doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? But he's been married for  twenty years--they've got six kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice smokescreen, isn't it? Tucker can hardly believe his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat does projects all over the world.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would I have seen your work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been to (thinking hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see--Santiago, Chile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely! I was there twice last  year.  Which building is yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know the...soccer stadium?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you build the Estadio Olympico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...just down the street, the Amigo  Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with it.  What style?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sort of nouveau deco...with a  big vestibule. Check it out next  time you're up there. Tucker starts to look a little suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I really should take your  card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noticing something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh look, it's Doob! Will you excuse  me a minute, Tucker? Healy drags Mary across the room toward a MAN who's looki at an exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dooby, you old sheep-fucker! How the  hell are ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Mel.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. Anyone ever tell you you  look just like Jim Dubois?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheepfucker? Healy shrugs and the man walks away angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-door Toyota Tercel flies by the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A determined Ted is cruising along the highway in his ren car. He has a cup of coffee in his hand and a HITCHHIKER in th seat beside him. The Hitchhiker sits with a LARGE RED DUF BAG between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for picking me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No prob, I could use the company.  I've been on the road going on fifteen  hours straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel--I been standing  in the same spot for the last five  hours. You know it's against the law  to pick up a hitchhiker in this state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must make it tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucks. So what's up? You some kind  of salesman or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. I'm...I'm nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A salesman--that's what I am. I mean,  I'm gonna be anyway. I'm starting my  own company--video sales--just as  soon as I get enough seed money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'That right? Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you wouldn't believe my idea-- it's a home run. You ever hear of  Eight-Minute Abs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exercise tape? Sure, I've seen  it on T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two million copies it sold last year.  Two million, man. But not next year-- my idea's gonna blow them outta the  water. Get this: (dramatic pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven-Minute Abs. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it. You walk into a video  store and you see Eight-Minute Abs  and right next to it you see Seven- Minute Abs--which one you gonna spring  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd go with the seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo. Especially since we guarantee  you'll get every bit as good a work- out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you guarantee that?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's the company motto: 'If you  ain't happy we'll send you the extra  minute.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. That sounds great. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless someone else comes out with  Six-Minute Abs. Ted CHUCKLES, but the Hitchhiker just GLARES at him, unam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unaware)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pull over. I gotta take a  leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Toyota Tercel pulls in and parks. Ted gets out and wa into the bushes to whiz. ON TED - as he steps into the dark brush UNZIPPING his fl he TRIPS over something and FALLS TO THE GROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the--? Suddenly WHOOSH, WHOOSH, WHOOSH--several huge SPOTLIGHTS  illuminate the area revealing TWO DOZEN FRIGHTENED MEN  scurrying to pull their pants up all around him.

dialogues.speaker: THIS IS A RAID
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON a startled Ted ON HIS KNEES directly in front of ANOTHER MAN, making it appear that he's been BLOWING THE  GUY. REVERSE ANGLE reveals a DOZEN POLICE OFFICERS holding the spotlights and moving in for the arrests followed by a CA CREW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deer caught in  headlights)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second, it's not what you  think. A GUY with his pants at his ankles jumps on the bandwagon
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right! I-I-I was just pissing! Ted glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I was pissing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll bet you all were. Come  on, in the truck. As they grab Ted and the others and hustle them away, we TO the Hitchhiker sitting in the Toyota watching the raid unfold. The Hitchhiker is clearly PANICKY at the sight of all the cops. Quietly he OPENS THE CAR DOOR, ducks down, and then SPRIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP OF TELEVISION SCREEN as the bust continues. Each the men COVER THEIR FACES as they pass by the camera, EXC FOR TED who is extremely visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, take it easy, you don't have  to push. REVERSE ANGLE REVEALS a shocked Dom and his wife watching this on their television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Is that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you he was gay. BACK ON THE TELEVISION - The COPS struggle to get the fei Ted into a police van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was taking a leak!
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be right back with more of our  special edition of COPS - LIVE IN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy and Mary are walking home at the end of their date. Healy is eating a big, wild cone of COTTON CANDY and drin a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That grandmother of yours--she's  really something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magda?  She's not my grandmother-- actually she rents the apartment  right next to mine.  Her husband  passed away a couple years ago so  she doesn't like to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it doesn't cramp your style?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadly, no. Well except for the lint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think it's that dog of hers  running around on the rug all day-- just makes for a lot of lint. Look  at this... Mary lifts her shirt, revealing a BIG CLUMP OF COTTON CAN STICKING OUT OF HER BELLY-BUTTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? That's just one day. Healy CRACKS UP and then gazes at her. What a babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, sometimes I wish I could  be like Magda and not go home. I'd  like to just bounce around for awhile,  do a little traveling...
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why bounce when you have your own  condo in Nepal to go to? It's clear Healy forgot about that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I'd sell that. Start fresh in a  new place, quit the architect game,  slow things down, read more books,  see more movies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a movie buff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to be. It's tough going with the  crap they make today. If Dumb and  Dumber's the best they've got to  offer I say thanks but no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But the Boston Globe critic Jay  Carr hated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fucking moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. I guess I just wish they made  them like they used to. You know,  something like The Heartbreak Kid...or  Harold and Maude. Mary can't believe her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Maude is my all-time  favorite movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. Come on, don't bust my chops.  I know it's corny, but I do love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, I'm not kidding. I really think  it's the greatest--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Love story of our time.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 Mary smiles. Is this guy for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I thought I was the only one. They come to her apartment building and stop. It gets a l awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...I guess this is it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll see ya. Healy turns to go but stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary ah, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, forget it, it was stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, what were you going to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, really, it was moronic. She grabs him by the shirt playfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say it. Healy takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I feel your bosoms before I  go? Mary just stares at him.
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out. Healy reaches out and cups her breasts. He doesn't kiss h she doesn't kiss him, he just fondles her breasts. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey-dokey, so tomorrow night? She smiles and as Healy walks away we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is sitting alone at a table in a small interrogation  room. PULLBACK to reveal that he is being observed through a tw way mirror by two detectives, FRANEK and CAVALLO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, they never look like you'd  expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably how he got the victim  to drop his guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd they find the body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a big red bag on the front  passenger seat. All hacked up--fucking  gruesome--a real psycho, this one. The Detectives ENTER the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands as the Detectives take a seat across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, I did not solicit  sex! I was just stopping to go the  bathroom, next thing I know I tripped  over something--well someone--and,  POOF, there's cops and lights and--
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, calm down, Ted, we believe  you. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is we found your friend  in the car. As Ted sits back down the Detectives just stare at him.  Finally Ted thinks he gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. The hitchhiker. (CHUCKLES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what this is all about. Ted puts his head in his hands and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that just my luck--I get caught  for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you admit it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guilty as charged. I'm not gonna  play games with you. I could give  you a song and dance but what's the  point? I did it and we all know it. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hitcher himself told me it's  illegal.  The irony. The Detectives are surprised by his forthrightness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, can you tell us his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, I didn't catch it. The Detectives flinch at his glib demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he was a stranger? It was totally  random?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the first hitcher I saw, what  can I tell you? Now cut to the chase,  how much trouble am I in?
Screenplay-There's_Something_About_Mary                p. 12-16-01 The Detectives look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First tell us why you did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I did it? (scoffs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
